attributes.description: The childless monarch of Ayodhyá who decrees a great sacrifice to obtain sons.
The chief priest and trusted guide of King Da[aratha, deeply read in Scripture.
The holy hermit and son of VibháGdak who guides the specific sacrificial forms of the Ashvamedha.
The chief queen of Da[aratha who participates in the rites, including the symbolic slaying of the steed.
The Supreme Lord who carries a shell, mace, and discus; he agrees to incarnate as Da[aratha's sons to slay RávaG.
The Creator who granted RávaG a boon of invulnerability against gods and demons, but not against men.
The Lord of the Sky and leader of the Gods who petitions VishGu for help against the giant RávaG.
The giant king whose pride and power torment the three worlds; he is immune to non-human entities.
The river on whose northern side the sacrificial ground for the Ashvamedha is prepared.
The kingdom ruled by King Janak, an old ally of Da[aratha.
The Sacrifice of the Steed, involving 21 sacrificial stakes and 300 victims to ensure the king's sovereignty and offspring.
The second rite begun by Rishya[ring using Atharva texts specifically to win sons for the king.
The sacred scriptures (including Rig, Yajur, Sama, and Atharva) that govern the ritual laws.
The King of Míthilá and ally invited to the sacrifice.
The King of the Angas invited to participate in the gathering.

attributes.context: Da[aratha initiates and funds the massive ritual to end his childless state.
Va[ishmha serves as the king's primary spiritual advisor and ritual director.
VishGu agrees to divide himself into four and be born as the king's offspring.
RávaG received a protective boon from Brahmá that fuels his senseless pride.
Indra leads the gods in praying to VishGu to provide a refuge from RávaG.
She performs the symbolic slaying of the sacrificial horse and stays by its side to ensure the birth of a son.
Janak is the imperial ruler of the Míthilá region.
He conducts the secondary rite using Atharva texts to finalize the king's request for sons.
He is deeply read in and ensures the sacrifice follows the six-fold science of the Vedas.
